newsitem.title: UK: IPE natgas gas softens after weekend flex sales.
newsitem.headline: IPE natgas gas softens after weekend flex sales.

text.p: IPE natural gas futures softened in early trade, after sales on the flexibility mechanism exerted pressure across the forward curve, brokers said.
Unseasonally warm temperatures over the Easter weekend forced TransCo to sell gas on the flex market below seven pence a therm (p/th), they said.
"The flex market sold over the weekend, that's always a negative sign for the market," said one dealer.
A total of 80 lots traded in the morning session, with most of the volume concentrated in the three front months.
May and June both slipped 0.05 p/th to 10.15 p/th, while July shed 0.125 to trade at $10.10 p/th.
Brokers said summer months were under pressure from an overhang of unsold gas.
Winter gas was untraded, but trade was done for spring 1998, with March 1998 losing 0.10 pence a therm to 13.90 p/th, and April sliding by 0.25 p/th to 12.5 p/th.
The Met Office said on Tuesday in its three-day forecast that it foresaw "rain in the north spreading southwards followed by much colder weather with wintry showers over Scotland."
